{{for|capital punishment in Northern Ireland|Capital punishment in the United Kingdom}} [[Capital punishment]] in the Republic of Ireland was abolished in [[statute law]] in 1990, having been abolished in 1964 for most offences including ordinary [[murder]]. The last to be executed was [[Michael Manning (murderer)|Michael Manning]], hanged for murder in 1954. All subsequent death sentences, the last handed down in 1985, were commuted by the [[President of Ireland|President]], on the advice of the [[Government of Ireland|Government]], to terms of imprisonment of up to 40 years. The [[Twenty-first Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|Twenty-first Amendment]] of the constitution, passed by referendum in 2001, prohibits the reintroduction of the death penalty, even during a [[state of emergency]] or war. Capital punishment is also forbidden by several human rights treaties to which the state is a party.
==Early history== [[Early Irish law]] discouraged capital punishment. Murder was usually punished with two types of fine: a fixed ''[[éraic]]'' and a variable ''Log nEnech''; a murderer was only killed if he and his relatives could not pay the fine.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kelly|first=Fergus |title=A Guide to Early Irish Law|series=Early Irish Law |year=1988 |publisher=Dublin Institute for Advanced Studies|isbn=978-1-85500-214-2|pages=125–7}}</ref> The ''[[Senchas Már]]'''s description of the execution of the murderer of [[Saint Patrick]]'s charioteer [[Odran (disciple of Saint Patrick)|Odran]] has been interpreted as a failed attempt to replace pagan [[restorative justice]] with Christian [[retributive justice]].<ref name="Bury2008">{{cite book|last=Bury|first=J. B.|title=Life of St. Patrick and His Place in History|url=https://archive.org/stream/lifeofstpatrickh00buryuoft#page/357/mode/1up |year=1905 |publisher=Macmillan |location=London |accessdate=6 November 2010|page=357}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Bracken|first=Damian|title=Immortality and capital punishment: patristic concepts in Irish law|journal=Peritia|volume=1995|issue=9|pages=167–186|issn=0332-1592|doi=10.1484/J.Peri.3.247}}</ref>
{{see also|Capital punishment in the United Kingdom}} After the [[Norman conquest of Ireland]], [[English law]] provided the model for Irish law. This originally mandated a death sentence for any [[felony]], a class of crimes established by [[common law]] but extended by various [[Act of Parliament|Acts of Parliament]];<ref name="lrcsentencing">{{cite web|url=http://www.lawreform.ie/_fileupload/consultation%20papers/cpSentencing.htm|title=The Evolution of Judicial Sentencing Discretion|date=March 1993|work=Consultation paper on sentencing|publisher=[[Law Reform Commission (Ireland)|Law Reform Commission]]|pages=72–3|accessdate=22 August 2011|location=Dublin}}</ref> a situation later dubbed the "[[Bloody Code]]". The [[gallows speech]] was a popular genre of [[Street literature|broadside]] from the [[Williamite War in Ireland|Williamite revolution]] through the eighteenth century, feeding into popular ballads of the nineteenth century.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ó Ciardha|first=Éamonn|date=Winter 2001|title=Review: ''Gallows Speeches from Eighteenth-Century Ireland'' by James Kelly|journal=History Ireland|volume=9|issue=4|url=http://www.historyireland.com/18th-19th-century-history/gallows-speeches-from-eighteenth-century-ireland/}}</ref>
The [[Criminal Law Act 1827]] allowed judges to sentence to [[penal transportation|transportation]] for many hitherto capital crimes.<ref name="lrcsentencing"/> For more, [[Peel's Acts]] in 1828 replaced the death penalty with [[penal servitude]]. The Capital Punishment (Ireland) Act 1842<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=V6hKAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA303 5 & 6 Vict c.28]</ref> brought the law in Ireland closer to that of England by reducing the penalties for numerous offences, and abolishing the capital crime of serving in the [[French Armed Forces|army or navy of France]]. The [[Offences Against the Person Act 1861]] reduced the number of capital crimes from over two hundred to just three: murder, treason and [[piracy]] with violence.<ref name="haughey1963">{{cite web|url=http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/debates%20authoring/debateswebpack.nsf/takes/dail1963110600038?opendocument|title=Criminal Justice Bill, 1963— Second Stage.|last=Haughey|first=Charles|date=6 November 1963|work=Dáil Éireann debates|pages=Vol. 205 No. 7 p.38 c.999|accessdate=18 April 2013}}</ref> Death was a [[mandatory sentence]] for murder, though it was often commuted.<ref>LRC Report 108 §2.59</ref> The last public hanging in Ireland was in 1868; after the [[Capital Punishment Amendment Act 1868]] executions were carried out behind prison walls. Irish doctor [[Samuel Haughton]] developed the humane [[Hanging#Standard drop|"Standard Drop"]] method of hanging that came into use in 1866. The last peacetime execution while Ireland was part of the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland]] was of William Scanlan in 1911 for murdering his sister-in-law.<ref name="cpuk">{{cite web |url=http://www.capitalpunishmentuk.org/ireland.html |title=20th century executions in the Irish Republic (Eire) |work=capitalpunishmentuk |first=Richard |last=Clark |accessdate=7 May 2015}}</ref>
Execution of [[Irish republicanism|Irish republicans]] created political [[martyr]]s, such as the "[[Manchester Martyrs]]" of 1867. The Prevention of Crime (Ireland) Act, 1882, was enacted during the [[Land War]] and introduced on the day of the funeral of [[Lord Frederick Cavendish]], one of the [[Phoenix Park murders|Phoenix Park murder]] victims.<ref name="Jackson2004">{{cite book|last=Jackson|first=Patrick|title=Harcourt and son: a political biography of Sir William Harcourt, 1827-1904|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y3f2twWl-jMC&pg=PA105|accessdate=2 November 2010|year=2004|publisher=Fairleigh Dickinson Univ Press|isbn=978-0-8386-4036-4|page=105}}</ref> This encouraged non-jury trials to impose death sentences, prompting [[Francis Alexander FitzGerald]] to resign in protest as [[baron of the exchequer]].<ref name="Heritage4"/> In fact no death sentence was passed under the provisions of that Act.<ref name="Heritage4">{{cite journal|title=On the Bench: The O’Briens & the Fitzgeralds|journal=Heritage Series|publisher=Courts Service of Ireland|issue=4|issn=1649-3850|url=http://courts.ie/Courts.ie/library3.nsf/(WebFiles)/60DB04323CA5F2A2802577910039A611/$FILE/Heritage%20series%20O%20Brien%20and%20Fitzgerald.pdf}}</ref>
==Revolutionary period== In 1916, the [[Easter Rising executions|execution of the leaders of the Easter Rising]] turned public sympathy in favour of the rebels. 24 rebels were executed during the [[Irish War of Independence|1919–21 War of Independence]], starting with [[Kevin Barry]].<ref name="cpuk"/><ref name="OGadhra"> {{cite news |url=http://archives.tcm.ie/businesspost/2001/10/14/story786314828.asp |title=Gone but not forgotten |last=O Gadhra |first=Nollaig |date=14 October 2001 |work=Sunday Business Post |accessdate=18 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050512121748/http://archives.tcm.ie/businesspost/2001/10/14/story786314828.asp |archivedate=12 May 2005 |df=dmy-all }} </ref> In [[Munster]], which was under [[martial law]], 13 were shot in Cork and one in Limerick.<ref name="OGadhra"/> "[[The Forgotten Ten]]" were hanged in [[Mountjoy Prison]], which helped turn opinion in Dublin against the [[Dublin Castle administration]].<ref name="OGadhra"/> The last United Kingdom execution was of William Mitchell, an [[Royal Irish Constabulary|RIC constable]] who had murdered a [[justice of the peace]].<ref> {{cite journal |last=Murphy |first=Brian P. |date=February 2005 |title=Kevin Myers and Propaganda |journal=Irish Political Review |publisher=Athol |volume=20 |issue=2 |page=16 |issn=0790-7672 |url=http://www.atholbooks.org/freemags/mags/IPR_February_2005.pdf#page=16 |format=PDF |accessdate=18 November 2009 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} </ref>
The self-proclaimed [[Irish Republic]], which fought the 1919–21 War against the British authorities, established [[Dáil Courts|its own republican courts]]. In summer 1920, when a [[County Meath]] republican court sentenced a man to death for murder, the sentence was referred to the [[Government of the 1st Dáil#2nd Ministry|Dáil ministry]], which decided to uphold it, although [[Constance Markievicz]] was reluctant.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Doyle |first1=David |last2=O’Callaghan |first2=Liam |title=Capital Crime: 1916 and Death Penalty Discourse in Independent Ireland {{!}} |url=https://www.rte.ie/centuryireland/index.php/articles/1916-and-death-penalty-discourse-in-independent-ireland |website=Century Ireland |publisher=RTÉ |accessdate=12 October 2018 |language=en}}</ref> The [[Irish Republican Army]] was empowered by the [[First Dáil]] to [[court-martial]] and execute pro-unionist civilians for such crimes as "spying" and [[Collaborationism|collaboration]]. The procedures at such trials depended on the local IRA leadership; many were [[kangaroo court]]s imposing summary justice. Besides executions, IRA members also carried out combat operations, assassinations, extra-judicial killings, and personally motivated murders, with varying levels of sanction from the republican leadership; historians have commented that the dividing lines between these categories can be blurred and contentious; an example being the 1922 [[Dunmanway killings]].<ref name="Cottrell2006">{{cite book|last=Cottrell|first=Peter|title=The Anglo-Irish War: The Troubles of 1913-1922|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qMpGh8UyICgC&pg=PA70|accessdate=31 October 2010|date=28 March 2006|publisher=Osprey Publishing|isbn=978-1-84603-023-9|pages=70–2}}</ref><ref name="ex220848">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/viewpoints/analysis/matters-of-life-and-death-220848.html|title=Matters of life and death|last=Dwyer|first=Ryle|date=28 January 2013|work=Irish Examiner|accessdate=5 May 2017}}</ref>
The 1922 committee drafting the [[Constitution of the Irish Free State]] submitted three drafts, of which Draft B explicitly prohibited the death penalty; the [[Provisional Government of Ireland (1922)|Provisional Government]]'s final draft was based on Draft B but deleted this prohibition.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Cahillane |first1=Laura |title=Drafting the Irish Free State Constitution |date=2016 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=9781526100573 |page=45 |url=https://books.google.ie/books?id=Li_VDgAAQBAJ&pg=PA45 |accessdate=12 October 2018 |language=en}}</ref> British laws prescribing the death penalty thus [[Reception statute|continued in force]].<ref name="grundy"> {{cite journal |url=http://www.ucd.ie/pages/99/articles/grundy.html |title=The Death Penalty in Ireland: A Legacy of the Civil War? |first=John |last=Grundy |publisher=UCD |journal=PaGes |volume=6 |year=1999 }}</ref> The death penalty was retained because of the outbreak of the [[Irish Civil War|1922–3 Civil War]].<ref name="grundy"/> As well as the existing British laws, the "Special Powers Act" (adopted in the form of a [[Resolution (law)|motion]] rather than an [[act of parliament]]) was passed by the [[Third Dáil]] on 26 September 1922 authorising military tribunals to impose death sentences on the anti-[[Anglo-Irish Treaty|Treaty]] forces.<ref name="grundy"/><ref> {{cite book |title=Dáil Éireann debates |publisher=Oireachtas |date=26 September 1922 |volume=1 |pages=cols.790–2 |nopp=Y |chapter=Motion by Minister for Defence |chapterurl=http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/Debates%20Authoring/DebatesWebPack.nsf/takes/dail1922092600027 }}; {{cite book |title=Dáil Éireann debates |publisher=Oireachtas |date=27 September 1922 |volume=1 |pages=cols.801–884 |nopp=Y |chapter=Motion by the Minister for Defence |chapterurl=http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/Debates%20Authoring/DebatesWebPack.nsf/takes/dail1922092700009#N19 }} </ref><ref>Regan 1999, pp.108–109</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1922/en/si/v19pg517.html|title=Military Courts - General Regulations As To Trial Of Civilians|date=2 October 1922|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=1 January 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150101214930/http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1922/en/si/v19pg517.html|archivedate=1 January 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> During the Civil War the [[Irish Free State|Free State]] government executed 81 captured anti-Treaty fighters by [[firing squad]],<ref name="grundy"/> as well as ordering [[extra-judicial killing]]s.<ref name="ex220848"/>
==Later executions== Between November 1923 and April 1954, there were a total of 35 executions in the state.<ref> [http://historical-debates.oireachtas.ie/D/0552/D.0552.200204230135.html Written Answers. - Capital Punishment] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607141710/http://historical-debates.oireachtas.ie/D/0552/D.0552.200204230135.html |date=7 June 2011 }} Dáil Éireann - Volume 552 - 23 April 2002 </ref> In the 1920s, execution was relatively common for murderers.<ref name="grundy"/> In the absence of a local [[executioner]], the Irish government retained the pre-independence custom of having a British hangman come to Mountjoy Prison to perform executions.<ref name="cpuk"/> There was local opposition to this, and in the 1940s an Irishman sent to Britain as apprentice to [[Albert Pierrepoint]] was deemed to lack "the character to be an executioner".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.ie/lifestyle/you-shall-hang-by-the-neck-1950237.html |title=You shall hang by the neck . . . |last=Corless |first=Damian |date=21 November 2009 |work=[[Irish Independent]] |accessdate=16 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/radio1/doconone/2016/0630/799314-irelands-secret-hangman/|title=Documentary on One- Ireland's Secret Hangman|last1=Kearney|first1=Joe|first2=Liam |last2=O'Brien|date=16 July 2016|work=RTÉ Radio 1|publisher=RTÉ|accessdate=16 July 2016}}</ref> 55 men and women were also sentenced to death in that time period but ultimately received a reprieve. Thirteen were sentenced for murdering their newborns, and 42 for other types of murder.<ref name="Wallace2016p4">{{Cite book |title=Sentenced to Death: Saved from the Gallows |last=Wallace |first=Colm |publisher=Somerville Press |year=2016 |isbn=9780992736491 |location=Banty |pages=4}}</ref>
The only woman executed after independence was Annie Walsh in 1925. She and her nephew blamed each other for the murder of her elderly husband. The press expected only the nephew to be found guilty, but both were. She was hanged aged 31 in spite of the jury recommending [[clemency]].<ref name="grundy"/><ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.tg4.ie/Bearla/scei/scei.asp?Dt=2009-8-27 |title=Thursday, 27.08.2009: 22:00 Ceart ‘s Coir |work=TV listings |accessdate=18 November 2009 |publisher=[[TG4]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20110716183006/http://www.tg4.ie/Bearla/scei/scei.asp?Dt=2009-8-27 |archivedate=16 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} </ref>
During the [[The Emergency (Ireland)|state of emergency in World War II]], increased IRA activity<ref>See: [[Irish Republican Army (1922-1969)#The IRA during World War II]]</ref> led to six executions.<ref name="anphoblacht">[http://www.anphoblacht.com/news/detail/35328 Remembering the Past: Executed IRA men reinterred] ''[[An Phoblacht]]''</ref> Five were shot by [[firing squad]] after sentence by [[military tribunal]]s under the [[Emergency Powers Act 1939]].<ref name="anphoblacht"/> Of these, Maurice O'Neill and Richard Goss had shot but not killed Gardaí: the only people executed by the state for a non-murder crime.<ref name="cpuk"/> [[Charlie Kerins]], the [[IRA Chief of Staff]], executed for murdering a Garda, was hanged rather than shot, making the point of treating him as a common criminal rather than a [[political crime|political prisoner]].<ref name="ex220848"/>
Harry Gleeson, hanged in 1941 for the 1940 [[murder of Moll McCarthy]], was granted a posthumous [[pardon]] in 2015.<ref name="jelrPR15000098">{{cite press release |url=http://www.justice.ie/en/JELR/Pages/PR15000098|title=Minister Fitzgerald announces Government decision to grant a Posthumous Pardon to Harry Gleeson|date=1 April 2015|publisher=Department of Justice and Equality|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref> [[Seán MacBride]] was Gleeson's defence counsel and attributed his later opposition to the death penalty to his belief in Gleeson's innocence.<ref name="it343559">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/gleeson-case-led-to-campaign-for-abolition-of-capital-punishment-1.343559|title=Gleeson case led to campaign for abolition of capital punishment|last=O Cathaoir|first=Brendan|date=27 December 2001|work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref> [[Michael Manning (carter)|Michael Manning]] was the last person executed in the state.<ref> [http://www.rte.ie/news/features/referenda/death/tonyconnelly1.html The referendum on capital punishment] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080403070534/http://www.rte.ie/news/features/referenda/death/tonyconnelly1.html |date= 3 April 2008 }} Tony Connelly, RTÉ, 2002 </ref> He was [[hanging|hanged]] for [[murder]] by [[Albert Pierrepoint]] on 20 April 1954. The same year, [[Brendan Behan]]'s play ''[[The Quare Fellow]]'' premiered, in which the title character was modelled on [[Bernard Kirwan]], awaiting execution in Mountjoy while Behan was imprisoned there.<ref>LRC Report 108 §2.61</ref>
==Legal developments== The 1922 "Special Powers Act" was replaced after the Civil War by a series of Public Safety Acts promoted by [[Cumann na nGaedheal]] governments to counter residual republican paramilitary activity. The 1923 act, valid for six months, allowed the death penalty for "armed revolt against the Government of Saorstát Eireann",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1923/en/act/pub/0028/sec0005.html#sec5|title=Public Safety (Emergency Powers) Act, 1923, Section 5|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=10 August 2014}}</ref> whereas the 1924 act, valid for one year, reduced this to life imprisonment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1924/en/act/pub/0015/print.html#sec1|title=Public Safety (Punishment of Offences) Temporary Act, 1924|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=10 August 2014}}</ref> The [[Treason in the Republic of Ireland|Treasonable Offences Act, 1925]] defined such offences as treason punishable by death. The Public Safety Act 1927, passed in response to the assassination of [[Kevin O'Higgins]],<ref>Regan 1999, pp.273–4</ref> provided for a special [[martial law|military tribunal]] during a [[state of emergency]], required the tribunal to pass death sentences for treason and murder, and permitted it to do so for unlawful possession of firearms; no [[appeal]] would be permitted.<ref name="act1927">[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1927/en/act/pub/0031/print.html Public Safety Act, 1927] [[Irish Statute Book]]</ref> The Act was originally to last five years, but was expired at the end of 1928.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1928/en/act/pub/0038/print.html|title=Public Safety Act, 1928|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=10 August 2014}}</ref> In 1931, [[Eoin O'Duffy]] used the threat posed by [[Saor Éire]] to press for a new Public Safety Act, the [[Constitution (Amendment No. 17) Act 1931]].<ref>Regan 1999, pp.287–8</ref><ref name="act1931">[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1931/en/act/pub/0037/print.html Constitution (Amendment No. 17) Act, 1931] Irish Statute Book</ref> This empowered the tribunal to try a variety of crimes and impose a greater sentence than usual, including death, if "in the opinion of the Tribunal such greater punishment is necessary or expedient".<ref name="act1931" /> This provision was condemned by the Fianna Fáil opposition<ref>{{cite journal|last=O'Connell|first=Rory|year=1999|title=Guardians of the Constitution: Unconstitutional Constitutional Norms|journal=Journal of Civil Liberties|pages=57–8|url=http://www.queens.ie/schools/SchoolofLaw/Staff/DrRoryOConnell/roryfiles/Filetoupload,101288,en.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721130228/http://www.queens.ie/schools/SchoolofLaw/Staff/DrRoryOConnell/roryfiles/Filetoupload%2C101288%2Cen.pdf|archivedate=21 July 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> (which came to power following the [[Irish general election, 1932|1932 general election]]) and was never invoked.
Fianna Fáil introduced a new Constitution in 1937, which contained several references to execution: ;Article 13 section 6: The [[prerogative of mercy|right of pardon and the power to commute or remit punishment]] imposed by any court exercising criminal jurisdiction are hereby vested in [[President of Ireland|the President]], but such power of commutation or remission may, except in capital cases, also be conferred by law on other authorities. ;Article 40 section 4: :;Subsection 5: Where an order is made under this section by the [[High Court (Ireland)|High Court]] or a judge thereof for the production of the body of a person who is under sentence of death, the High Court or such judge thereof shall further order that the execution of the said sentence of death shall be deferred until after [[habeas corpus|the body of such person has been produced]] before the High Court and the lawfulness of his detention has been determined and if, after such deferment, the detention of such person is determined to be lawful, the High Court shall appoint a day for the execution of the said sentence of death and that sentence shall have effect with the substitution of the day so appointed for the day originally fixed for the execution thereof. :;Subsection 6: Nothing in this section, however, shall be invoked to prohibit, control, or interfere with any act of [[Irish Defence Forces|the Defence Forces]] during the existence of a state of war or armed rebellion.
[[Infanticide]] was made a separate crime from murder in 1949.<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1949/en/act/pub/0016/index.html Infanticide Act, No. 16/1949] Irish Statute Book</ref> Since independence, all 13 death sentences for murder in such cases had been [[commutation of sentence|commuted]];<ref name="Wallace2016p4"/><ref name="Rattigan2008">{{cite journal|last=Rattigan|first=Clíona|year=2008|title=‘Done to death by father or relatives’: Irish families and infanticide cases, 1922–1950|journal=The History of the Family|volume=13|issue=4|pages=370–383|issn=1081-602X|doi=10.1016/j.hisfam.2008.09.003}}</ref> the new act was intended "to eliminate all the terrible ritual of the black cap and the solemn words of the judge pronouncing sentence of death in those cases ... where it is clear to the Court and to everybody, except perhaps the unfortunate accused, that the sentence will never be carried out."<ref>[http://historical-debates.oireachtas.ie/S/0036/S.0036.194907070006.html Infanticide Bill, 1949—Second and Subsequent Stages] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120922040131/http://historical-debates.oireachtas.ie/S/0036/S.0036.194907070006.html |date=22 September 2012 }} Seanad Éireann debates - Vol.36 c.1472 - 7 July 1949</ref> Most cases were not prosecuted as murder before 1949, and a murder charge was still possible after then.<ref name="Maguire2013">{{cite book|last=Maguire|first=Moira J.|title=Precarious Childhood in Post-Independence Ireland|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=uDeLCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT194|accessdate=2017-05-05|date=2013-07-19|publisher=Manchester University Press|isbn=9781847797599|chapter=Sanctity of child life? Official responses to infanticide}}</ref>
The Criminal Justice Act 1951, in conformance with Article 13.6 of the Constitution, explicitly excluded capital cases from those to which [[Government of Ireland|the Government]] was granted the power to commute sentences.<ref>{{cite book|title=Criminal Justice Act, 1951|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1951/en/act/pub/0002/sec0023.html|series=Irish Statute Book|volume=1951, No. 2|date=21 February 1951|page=§23 (1)|nopp=Y|chapter=Remission of punishment, forfeitures and disqualifications. }}</ref>
Successive [[Minister for Justice and Equality|Ministers for Justice]] were asked in the Dáil about abolishing the death penalty: in 1936 by [[Frank MacDermot]];<ref> [https://web.archive.org/web/20110609215234/http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0060/D.0060.193602190006.html Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Death Penalty] Dáil Éireann - Volume 60 - 19 February 1936 </ref> in 1939 by [[Jeremiah Hurley]];<ref> [http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0074/D.0074.193902080010.html Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Abolition of Death Penalty.] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20121218212508/http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0074/D.0074.193902080010.html |date=18 December 2012 }} Dáil Éireann - Volume 74 - 8 February 1939 </ref> in 1948 by [[James Larkin Jnr]]<ref> [https://web.archive.org/web/20110609215534/http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0110/D.0110.194805050040.html Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Abolition of Death Penalty.] Dáil Éireann - Volume 110 - 05 May, 1948 </ref> and [[Peadar Cowan]];<ref> [http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0113/D.0113.194812090067.html Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Inquiry into Death Penalty.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609215717/http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0113/D.0113.194812090067.html |date=9 June 2011 }} Dáil Éireann - Volume 113 - 9 December 1948 </ref> in 1956 by [[Thomas Finlay (judge)|Thomas Finlay]];<ref> [https://web.archive.org/web/20050427101209/http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0155/D.0155.195603140009.html Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Death Penalty.] Dáil Éireann - Volume 155 - 14 March 1956 </ref> in 1960 by [[Frank Sherwin]];<ref> [http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0181/D.0181.196005120018.html Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Abolition of Death Penalty.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609220515/http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0181/D.0181.196005120018.html |date=9 June 2011 }} Dáil Éireann - Volume 181 - 12 May 1960 </ref> in 1962 by [[Stephen Coughlan]].<ref> [https://web.archive.org/web/20110609220526/http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0198/D.0198.196211270050.html Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Death Penalty.] Dáil Éireann - Volume 198 - 27 November 1962 </ref> In each case the relevant minister dismissed the suggestion. [[Seán MacBride]] expressed personal support for abolition even while a minister in a government that oversaw the 1948 execution of William M. Gambon.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://irishcriminology.com/10b-A-Short-History-Of-Capital-Punishment.html |title=A Coalition of Sorts 1948-54 |work=A Short History of capital Punishment In Ireland |publisher=Irish-criminology.com |accessdate=18 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090625132604/http://irishcriminology.com/10b-A-Short-History-Of-Capital-Punishment.html |archivedate=25 June 2009 |df=dmy-all }} </ref> In 1951–52, MacBride's Dáil motion that a [[Select Committee]] consider whether to abolish the death penalty was defeated by 63 votes to 23.<ref>LRC Report 108 §2.60; ''Dáil Debates'' "Private Deputies' Business. — Abolition of Capital Punishment—Motion" [http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/debates%20authoring/debateswebpack.nsf/takes/dail1951112100067 21 November 1951 Vol.127 cc.1158–1166], [http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/debates%20authoring/debateswebpack.nsf/takes/dail1951120500060 5 December 1951 Vol.128 cc.409–434], [http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/debates%20authoring/debateswebpack.nsf/takes/dail1952013000067 30 January 1952 Vol.129 cc.137–154] </ref> In 1956, the Seanad passed a motion "That in the opinion of Seanad Eireann the Government should consider the question of introducing legislation to abolish capital punishment or to suspend it for an experimental period".<ref>LRC Report 108 §2.60; {{cite web|url=http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/debates%20authoring/debateswebpack.nsf/takes/seanad1956053000010?opendocument|title=Capital Punishment—Motion.|date=30 May 1956|work=Seanad Éireann debates|publisher=Oireachtas|pages=Vol. 46 No. 2 p.10 cc.172–208|accessdate=18 April 2013}}</ref>
When [[Seán Brady (Irish politician)|Seán Brady]] asked in February 1963, minister [[Charles Haughey]] announced "that the death penalty for murder generally will be abolished but it will be retained for certain specific types of murder."<ref> [https://web.archive.org/web/20110609220541/http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0199/D.0199.196301240050.html Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Abolition of Death Penalty.] Dáil Éireann - Volume 199 - 24 January 1963 </ref> In 1984 Haughey said, "Very shortly after becoming minister for justice, I went up to Mountjoy to see the condemned cell and I was so revolted by the whole atmosphere that I resolved to do away with the death penalty."<ref name="ex220848"/> The Criminal Justice Act 1964 abolished the death penalty for piracy, some military crimes, and most murders. It continued to be available for:<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1964/en/act/pub/0005/print.html Criminal Justice Act 1964] Irish Statute Book, Acts of the Oireachtas</ref> * [[Treason in the Republic of Ireland|treason]] —under Article 39 of the Constitution, "treason shall consist only in levying war against the State, or assisting any State or person or inciting or conspiring with any person to levy war against the State, or attempting by force of arms or other violent means to overthrow the organs of government established by the Constitution, or taking part or being concerned in or inciting or conspiring with any person to make or to take part or be concerned in any such attempt."<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1939/en/act/pub/0010/index.html#zza10y1939 Treason Act 1939] Irish Statute Book, Acts of the Oireachtas</ref> * offences under [[military law]], relating to<ref>§§124, 125, 127, and 128, [http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1954/en/act/pub/0018/index.html#zza18y1954 Defence Act 1954] Irish Statute Book, Acts of the Oireachtas</ref> **neglect of [[Officer (armed forces)|command]] **assisting the enemy **passivity as a [[prisoner of war]] **[[mutiny]] * "capital murder", i.e. ** of an [[Garda Síochána|Garda]] or prison officer "acting in the course of his duty"; or ** for a [[political crime|political motive]], of a foreign head of state, diplomat, or government member; or ** in the course or furtherance of certain offences under the [[Offences against the State Act 1939]]:<ref>§§6, 7, 8, and 9, [http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1939/en/act/pub/0013/print.html Offences Against the State Act, 1939] Irish Statute Book, Acts of the Oireachtas</ref> ***Usurpation of functions of government ***Obstruction of government ***Obstruction of the President ***Interference with military or other employees of the State
The Extradition Act, 1965 prevented [[extradition]] where the prisoner could be sentenced to death for a crime not punishable by death in Ireland.<ref>{{cite book|title=Extradition Act, 1965|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1965/en/act/pub/0017/sec0019.html|series=Irish Statute Book|volume=1965, No. 19|date=19 July 1965|page=§19|nopp=Y|chapter=Capital punishment. }}</ref>
The meaning of "capital murder" under the 1964 act was elucidated by the [[Supreme Court (Ireland)|Supreme Court]] in the 1977 case of [[Noel and Marie Murray]], convicted of capital murder after the 1975 shooting of a Garda, who was off duty and not in uniform, giving chase after they had robbed a bank. The court held that "capital murder" was a new offence, not merely a subtype of the existing [[Common law|common-law]] offence of murder; and that the Garda was acting "in the course of his duty", despite not being on duty; but that, as he was in plain clothes, the Murrays did not know he was a Garda; and so, while there was intent (''[[mens rea]]'') to commit murder, there was no intent to commit capital murder.<ref>People (DPP) v Murray [1977] IR 360; {{cite journal |title=Capital Murder and the Supreme Court |first=Paul |last=O'Connor |journal=Irish Jurist |volume=New series, Vol. 14 |number=2 |date=Winter 1979 |pages=329–333 |jstor=44027413 }}</ref>
==Commuted death sentences== From 1923 to 1964, 40 death sentences were commuted to life imprisonment; three condemned were found insane, and three died awaiting execution.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0205/D.0205.196310240098.html |series=Dáil Éireann debates |volume=204 |date=24 October 1963 |title=Questions. Oral Answers. — Commuting of Death Sentences. |accessdate=14 July 2010 |pages=cols.324–5 |nopp=Y |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609130718/http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0205/D.0205.196310240098.html |archivedate=9 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Criminology professor Ian O'Donnell wrote in 2016 that murderers with commuted death sentences "were released after periods of time that would be considered absurdly short today".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/legal-opinion-death-of-capital-punishment-does-not-end-law-and-order-1.2487037 |title=Legal Opinion: Death of capital punishment does not end law and order |first=Ian |last=O'Donnell |newspaper=The Irish Times |date=8 January 2016 |accessdate=7 May 2017}}</ref> In the years 1946–62, 82 murders produced 73 arrests; of these 34 were [[unfit to plead]] because of insanity, 7 found [[guilty but insane]], and 18 found guilty and thus [[Mandatory sentencing|mandatorily sentenced]] to death.<ref name="haughey1963"/> The sentences were executed on 3 and commuted on the other 15, including all three women.<ref name="haughey1963"/> [[Mamie Cadden]] was sentenced to be hanged in 1957 for [[felony murder rule|felony murder]] after performing an [[Abortion in the Republic of Ireland|illegal abortion]] on a woman who died.
Death sentences were passed on 11 people after the 1964 Act, for 5 different incidents involving the capital murder of a total of 6 Gardaí (police). All were imposed by the [[Special Criminal Court]]. The murders of several other gardaí, and of British ambassador [[Christopher Ewart-Biggs]] in 1976, might also have constituted capital crimes had any prosecution been brought. Of the 11 sentenced to death, 2 had the conviction for capital murder quashed on appeal, and were convicted instead of ordinary murder.<ref name="burke1990">{{cite journal |url=http://historical-debates.oireachtas.ie/D/0399/D.0399.199006010003.html |series=Dáil Éireann debates |volume=399 |date=1 June 1990 |title=Criminal Justice (No. 2) Bill, 1990: Second Stage. |accessdate=14 July 2010 |pages=col.1194 |nopp=Y |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607205736/http://historical-debates.oireachtas.ie/D/0399/D.0399.199006010003.html |archivedate=7 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The death sentences of the other 9 were commuted by the President on the advice of the government, to 40 years' imprisonment without [[parole]].<ref name="burke1990"/> One conviction was overturned in 1995. The 40-year sentences were controversial, both because they had no statutory basis,<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0337/D.0337.198206300010.html |series=Dáil Éireann debates |volume=337 |date=30 June 1982 |title=Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Commuting of Death Sentence |accessdate=14 July 2010 |pages=cols.338–340 |nopp=Y |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609131018/http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0337/D.0337.198206300010.html |archivedate=9 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and because they were not handed down by a judge. The [[Court of Criminal Appeal (Ireland)|Court of Criminal Appeal]] has upheld the sentences as the extra-judicial procedure is in step with the Irish Constitution's provision for commuting sentences.
Four convicts were released in 1998 under the amnesty of political prisoners under the [[Good Friday Agreement]]. The remaining four protested that they were also eligible for the amnesty, but were not released under its provisions. The state refused to grant the standard remission of sentences due for good behaviour, which would make them eligible for parole after 30 years.<ref name="ind29657572">{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/two-garda-killers-who-faced-death-penalty-have-been-freed-from-prison-29657572.html|title=Two garda killers who faced death penalty have been freed from prison|last=Brady|first=Tom|date=14 October 2013|work=[[Irish Independent]]|accessdate=10 August 2014}}</ref> One of the four, Noel Callan, took a court case that he was entitled to emission, which was rejected by the High Court in 2011,<ref name="iehc2011_190" /> but upheld by the Supreme Court in 2013.<ref name="ind29657572"/><ref>{{cite BAILII |litigants= Callan -v- Ireland & anor |court=IESC |year=2013 |num=35 |date=2013-07-18 |courtname=Supreme Court |juris=Ireland}}</ref> Two of the four, who had already served over thirty years, were released straight away, while Callan and the fourth were released in December 2015 upon reaching 30 years.<ref name="ind29657572"/><ref name="it2451758">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/garda-murderers-freed-from-jail-after-three-decades-1.2451758|title=Garda murderers freed from jail after three decades|last=Lally|first=Conor|date=2 December 2015|work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=1 January 2016}}</ref>

==Abolition== [[Noel Browne]] introduced a [[private member's bill|private member's bill]] to abolish the death penalty in March 1981.<ref name="Browne1981">{{cite book |title=Private Members' Business. - Criminal Justice Bill, 1981: First Stage (Resumed) |url=http://historical-debates.oireachtas.ie/D/0328/D.0328.198105050078.html |series=Dáil Éireann debates |volume=328 |date=5 May 1981 |pages=cols.2150–8 |nopp=Y |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607201649/http://historical-debates.oireachtas.ie/D/0328/D.0328.198105050078.html |archivedate=7 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The [[Fianna Fáil]] government voted it down on its [[first reading]].<ref name="Browne1981"/> [[Fine Gael]] had supported the first reading and would have allowed a [[free vote]] at the second reading; the [[Labour Party (Ireland)|Labour Party]] supported abolition.<ref name="Browne1981"/> The [[the Troubles|Troubles]] were then ongoing, and the Minister for Justice, [[Gerry Collins (politician)|Gerry Collins]], in opposing the bill, referred to the four death sentences which were then pending appeal, and said "were we to abolish [the death penalty], and because of the violence of recent years, the pressure for arming the Garda would become extremely strong".<ref name="Browne1981"/> After the [[Irish general election, 1981|general election in June 1981]], the [[Government of the 22nd Dáil|Fine Gael–Labour coalition]] introduced a bill in the [[Seanad Éireann|Seanad]] to abolish the death penalty for treason and capital murder, which passed there but had not reached the Dáil when the government fell [[Irish general election, February 1982|in January 1982]].<ref>LRC Report 108, §2.64; Seanad Éireann - Volume 96 [https://web.archive.org/web/20070824205538/http://oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/S/0096/S.0096.198110150005.html cols 218–252] [http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/S/0096/S.0096.198110290007.html cols 460–512] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609125700/http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/S/0096/S.0096.198110290007.html |date=9 June 2011 }} [http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/S/0096/S.0096.198111050003.html cols 528–560] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609125730/http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/S/0096/S.0096.198111050003.html |date=9 June 2011 }} [https://web.archive.org/web/20110609130618/http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/S/0096/S.0096.198111120004.html cols 644–706] </ref> Another private member's bill, introduced by [[Shane Ross]] in 1984, began its second reading in 1985,<ref>LRC Report 108, §2.64; Seanad Éireann [http://debates.oireachtas.ie/seanad/1984/05/15/00005.asp Vol.103 No.12 p.5 cc.1117–8], [http://debates.oireachtas.ie/seanad/1985/02/13/00007.asp Vol.107 No.3 p.7 cc.277–87], [http://debates.oireachtas.ie/seanad/1985/02/13/00009.asp p.9 cc.287–304], [http://debates.oireachtas.ie/seanad/1985/02/20/00008.asp No.5 p.8 cc.431–56] </ref> but was still on the order paper in 1990.<ref>Seanad Éireann [http://debates.oireachtas.ie/seanad/1989/05/24/00004.asp Vol. 122 No. 19 p.4 cc.1998–2008] [http://debates.oireachtas.ie/seanad/1990/02/07/00004.asp Vol. 123 No. 15 p.4 cc.1671–82] </ref> A 1986 [[Department of Foreign Affairs (Ireland)|Department of Foreign Affairs]] briefing made public in 2017 said:<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/death-penalty-state-papers-3135198-Jan2017/|title=Ireland's death penalty was a 'quaint throwback' but not everyone wanted to get rid of it|last=Duffy|first=Rónán|date=1 January 2017|work=[[TheJournal.ie]]|accessdate=7 May 2017}}</ref> :The death penalty in this country is largely a quaint throwback to the days when everyone else had one. As we no longer have a hangman, and almost the only country in the world in a position to train one is [[Apartheid South Africa|South Africa]], there is no immediate prospect of execution in this jurisdiction. That being said, the abolition of the death penalty would represent a strong political minus in the eyes of certain right-wing groupings, including the gardaí, the [[Royal Ulster Constabulary|RUC]] and the [[Democratic Unionist Party|DUP]]. While the step would be practically meaningless, it could be used in a politically damaging way.
In 1988, the [[Progressive Democrats]] (PDs) produced an aspirational "Constitution for a New Republic", which included a prohibition on capital punishment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.michaelpidgeon.com/manifestos/docs/pd/Progressive%20Democrats%20Constitution%201988.pdf#page=3|title=Constitution for a New Republic|date=January 1988|work=Irish Election Manifesto Archive|publisher=Michael Pidgeon|page=4|accessdate=22 August 2011 |quote=The State shall not make lawful the taking of life as punishment for any offence}}</ref>
Ireland's 1989 [[ratification]] of the [[International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]] (ICCPR), effective 8 March 1990, made a [[reservation (law)|reservation]] to Article 6(5). The Article reads "Sentence of death shall not be imposed for crimes committed by persons below eighteen years of age and shall not be carried out on pregnant women."<ref> Art 6(5), [http://www2.ohchr.org/english/law/ccpr.htm#part3 International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705115024/http://www2.ohchr.org/english/law/ccpr.htm |date= 5 July 2008 }}. [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights]] </ref> The Irish government's declaration read "Pending the introduction of further legislation to give full effect to the provisions of paragraph 5 of Article 6, should a case arise which is not covered by the provisions of existing law, the Government of Ireland will have regard to its obligations under the Covenant in the exercise of its power to advise commutation of the sentence of death."<ref name="unts1551"> {{cite journal |year=1997 |title=No. 14668. International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights |journal=United Nations Treaty Series |publisher=United Nations |location=New York |volume=1551 |page=352 |url=http://treaties.un.org/doc/Publication/UNTS/Volume%201551/v1551.pdf#page=370 |format=PDF }} </ref> The legislation referred to was the Child Care Bill 1988,<ref name="dailv403c2635"/> which became law in 1991;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1991/en/act/pub/0017/index.html|title=Child Care Act, 1991|work=Irish Statute Book|publisher=Government of Ireland|accessdate=12 December 2010}}</ref> a section was to have been included to raise from 17 to 18 the minimum age for the death penalty.<ref name="dailv403c2635"/> In May 1989, Fianna Fáil minister [[Michael Woods (politician)|Michael Woods]] stated:<ref name="dailv390c1045">{{cite web|url=http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0390/D.0390.198905240017.html|title=Oral Answers. - Death Penalty|date=24 May 1989|work=Dáil debates|publisher=Oireachtas|pages=Vol.390 cc.1045–7|accessdate=12 December 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120825125543/http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0390/D.0390.198905240017.html|archivedate=25 August 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> :I appreciate that there is support for the abolition of the death penalty and, in more normal times, I accept that there would be merit in a full and open debate on the pros and cons of such a move. However, times are not normal and there are armed subversive groups inimical to the institutions of the State. In such circumstances my primary concern — and that of the Minister for Justice — is to provide the maximum protection possible for those who defend our democratic institutions. I am concerned that a move to abolish the death penalty at present could give the wrong signal. It would remove the additional protection which the death penalty provides for members of the Garda Síochána and the Prison Service, who are especially at risk from violent criminals, some of whom have been murdered in the execution of their duty.
After the [[Irish general election, 1989|June 1989 general election]], Fianna Fáil formed a coalition with the PDs;<ref>See: [[Government of the 26th Dáil]]</ref> the agreed programme for government included abolishing the death penalty.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.michaelpidgeon.com/manifestos/docs/pfgs/PfG%201989%20-%201993%20-%20FF-PD.pdf#page=16|title=Agreed programme for Government 1989–1993|last=Progressive Democrats|date=July 1989|work=Irish Election Manifesto Archive|publisher=Michael Pidgeon|page=32|quote=new laws, removing the death penalty; changing the libel laws; and governing telephone tapping will be introduced.|accessdate=22 August 2011}}</ref> It was abolished for all offences by the Criminal Justice Act 1990,<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1990/en/act/pub/0016/print.html Criminal Justice Act 1990] Irish Statute Book, Acts of the Oireachtas</ref> which made [[Life imprisonment in Ireland|life imprisonment]] the penalty for what had been capital crimes, and all except the military crimes had a minimum term of not less than forty years; remission rules are stricter than for other crimes.<ref>LRC 108, §§2.66–2.67</ref> The Child Care Bill 1988 was still pending, so the section relating to the death penalty was removed as superfluous.<ref name="dailv403c2635">[http://debates.oireachtas.ie/dail/1990/12/13/00021.asp#N444 Dáil debates, Vol.403 c.2635]</ref> In 1993, the then [[Tánaiste]], [[Dick Spring]], said in Vienna that the 1990 abolition should be made irreversible, which [[Taoiseach]] [[Albert Reynolds]] later confirmed was government policy and would involve a constitutional amendment.<ref> col.608–9, [https://web.archive.org/web/20110609220622/http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0432/D.0432.199306150004.html Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Constitutional Reform.] Dáil Éireann - Volume 432 - 15 June 1993 </ref> However, the government fell six months later.
One recommendation of the 1996 Constitutional Review Group was:<ref> {{cite book |author=Constitution Review Group |title=Report of the Constitution Review Group |chapter=Articles 40 - 44; 6: appeals relating to death sentences |url=http://www.constitution.ie/reports/crg.pdf#page=263 |page=262 |archivedate=21 July 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721123405/http://www.constitution.ie/reports/crg.pdf |format=pdf |location=Dublin |publisher=Stationery Office |year=1996 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> :Prohibit the re-introduction of the death penalty. If this is not deemed desirable, Article 40.4.5° should be retained. If it is prohibited, Article 28.3.3° will require amendment so that the death penalty cannot be imposed in any circumstances. Article 40.4.5° prescribed the treatment of those under sentence of death; Article 28.3.3° deals with the suspension of rights during a [[state of emergency]]. On 7 June 2001, the [[Twenty-first Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland]] was one of three proposed amendments put to referendums. It added Article 15.5.2°, which prohibits the death penalty; deleted as redundant Article 40.4.5° and several other references to "capital crimes"; and amended Article 28.3.3° to prevent the death penalty being imposed during an emergency.<ref> [http://www.referendum.ie/archive/display.asp?ballotid=16&page=0 Prohibition of Death Penalty (2001): The Twenty-first Amendment of the Constitution (No. 2) Bill, 2001 7-June-2001] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041028101429/http://www.referendum.ie/archive/display.asp?ballotid=16 |date=28 October 2004 }} Returning Officer for referendums in Ireland </ref><ref>[http://www.refcom.ie/en/Pastreferendums/AbolitionoftheDeathPenalty/ Past referendums: Abolition of the Death Penalty] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091017062512/http://www.refcom.ie/en/Pastreferendums/AbolitionoftheDeathPenalty/# |date=17 October 2009 }} Referendum Commission (Ireland)</ref> The [[Referendum Commission]] produced an information booklet, with arguments for and against the amendment derived from submissions it had solicited from the public.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.refcom.ie/en/Past-Referendums/Abolition-of-the-Death-Penalty/Arguments-For-and-Against/|title=Abolition of the Death Penalty: Arguments For and Against|year=2001|work=Past Referendums|publisher=Referendum Commission|accessdate=7 May 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170419175605/http://refcom.ie/en/Past-Referendums/Abolition-of-the-Death-Penalty/Arguments-For-and-Against/#|archive-date=19 April 2017|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The amendment was passed on a [[voter turnout|turnout]] of 34.79%, with 610,455 in favour and 372,950 against.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.environ.ie/en/LocalGovernment/Voting/Referenda/PublicationsDocuments/FileDownLoad,1894,en.pdf#page=60 |title=Referendum Results 1937–2009 |year=2011 |publisher=Department of the Environment, Heritage and Local Government |page=60 |accessdate=22 August 2011 |location=Dublin |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726184747/http://www.environ.ie/en/LocalGovernment/Voting/Referenda/PublicationsDocuments/FileDownLoad%2C1894%2Cen.pdf |archivedate=26 July 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> The 38% no-vote was higher than the 28% predicted by polls; there were suggestions that the wording of the ballot question was confusing and that some voters were expressing dissatisfaction with the government.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/archive/2001/0609/Pg008.html#Ar00803|title=Confusion prompts rise in support for death penalty|last=Coulter|first=Carol|date=9 June 2001|work=[[The Irish Times]]|page=8|accessdate=22 August 2011}}</ref>
Ireland adopted the Second Optional Protocol to the ICCPR in 1993,<ref name="unts1725"> {{cite journal |year=2000 |title=No. 14668. International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights |journal=United Nations Treaty Series |publisher=United Nations |location=New York |volume=1725 |page=374 |url=http://treaties.un.org/doc/Publication/UNTS/Volume%201725/v1725.pdf#page=404 |format=PDF }} </ref><ref> [https://web.archive.org/web/20110609220705/http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0437/D.0437.199401260054.html Written Answers. - International Agreements.] Dáil Éireann - Volume 437 - 26 January 1994 </ref> and the Sixth Protocol to the [[European Convention on Human Rights]] (ECHR) in 1994,<ref name="coe-ratifications"> [http://conventions.coe.int/Treaty/Commun/ListeTraites.asp?PO=IRE&MA=3&SI=2&DF=&CM=3&CL=ENG Ireland: Human Rights (Convention and Protocols only): Treaties signed and ratified or having been the subject of an accession] 18 November 2009 [[Council of Europe]] </ref> both of which prohibit the death penalty in peacetime.<ref> [https://web.archive.org/web/20040820043218/http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0482/D.0482.199710230017.html Adjournment Debate. - Death Penalty.] Dáil Éireann - Volume 482 - 23 October 1997, col.322–3 </ref> The reservation to ICCPR Article 6(5) was withdrawn in 1994.<ref name="iccpr">fn.25, [http://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=IV-4&chapter=4&lang=en#25 International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights: Signatories] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100901184638/http://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=IV-4&chapter=4&lang=en |date= 1 September 2010 }} United Nations Treaty Series, Chapter IV, No. 4 </ref> Ireland ratified the Thirteenth Protocol to the ECHR, which prohibits the death penalty in wartime, at its opening in 2002.<ref name="coe-ratifications"/>
==Debate== The media occasionally reports calls to reconsider the ban on capital punishment. In November 2009, [[Richard Johnson (judge)|Richard Johnson]], recently retired as President of the [[High Court (Ireland)|High Court]], said that he favoured reintroduction of the death penalty in limited circumstances, such as murder committed during [[armed robbery|armed robberies]].<ref> {{cite news |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/frontpage/2009/1116/1224258922186.html |title=Death penalty should be revisited, says ex-judge |last=Coulter |first=Carol |date=16 November 2009 |work=The Irish Times |page=1 |accessdate=16 November 2009 }} </ref> The [[Irish Council for Civil Liberties]] described his remarks as "deeply misguided and frivolous".<ref>[http://www.iccl.ie/news/2009/11/16/judge%E2%80%99s-death-penalty-remarks-%E2%80%9Cdeeply-misguided-and-frivolous%E2%80%9D-says-iccl-2.html Judge’s Death Penalty Remarks “Deeply Misguided and Frivolous”, says ICCL] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727115507/http://www.iccl.ie/news/2009/11/16/judge%E2%80%99s-death-penalty-remarks-%E2%80%9Cdeeply-misguided-and-frivolous%E2%80%9D-says-iccl-2.html |date=27 July 2011 }} 16 November 2009, Irish Council for Civil Liberties</ref> At the January 2010 meeting of the [[Mid-West Regional Authority]], two members of [[Clare County Council]] called for "a public debate" on the death penalty.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0107/1224261823333.html|title=Councillors call for debate on death penalty|date=7 January 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=7 September 2011}}</ref> In June 2010, [[Kevin Kiely (politician)|Kevin Kiely]], then outgoing mayor of [[Limerick]], advocated the death penalty for "anyone involved in the planning and [[Premeditated murder|premeditation]] of a murder" in the aftermath of several gang-related murders.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/limerick-mayor-wants-death-penalty-restored-2209814.html|title=Limerick mayor wants death penalty restored|last=Duggan|first=Barry|date=6 June 2010|work=Sunday Independent|accessdate=22 August 2011}}</ref>
The [[National Party (Ireland, 2016)|National Party]], a right-wing group established in 2016,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/politics/farright-partys-launch-is-cancelled-35222497.html|title=Far-right party's launch is cancelled|last=Larkin|first=Laura|date=17 November 2016|work=[[Irish Independent]]|accessdate=13 April 2018}}; {{cite news|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/justin-barrett-national-party-3089289-Nov2016/|title=Who is National Party leader Justin Barrett? |last=MacNamee|first=Garreth|date=18 November 2016|work=[[TheJournal.ie]]|accessdate=13 April 2018}}</ref> supports reintroduction of the death penalty for "particularly heinous crimes".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalparty.ie/principles/|publisher =National Party|title=Principles|access-date=23 May 2017}}</ref>

'''[[Capital punishment]]''' has been abolished in [[Turkey]] as of 2004, and Turkey has not executed any prisoners since October 1984.<ref>https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/08/07/tayyip-erdogan-hints-at-return-of-death-penalty-in-turkey/</ref>
==History== Prior to 1984, executions would usually happen after military interventions. [[Adnan Menderes]], who served as Prime Minister was hanged on 17 September 1961 following the [[1960 Turkish coup d'état|1960 coup d'état]], along with two other cabinet members, [[Fatin Rüştü Zorlu]] and [[Hasan Polatkan]]. The student leaders [[Deniz Gezmiş]], Hüseyin İnan and Yusuf Aslan were hanged on 6 May 1972 after the [[1971 Turkish military memorandum|1971 military memorandum]]. Following the [[1980 Turkish coup d'état|1980 coup d'état]], between 1980 and 1984, a total of 50 men, including 27 political activists, were executed by Turkish authorities.<ref>A [http://www.belgenet.com/12eylul/12eylidam.html complete list of all executed people] (in Turkish), accessed on 10 September 2009</ref>
Twenty-four articles of the 1926 Turkish Penal Code (Law 765) provided for a mandatory death penalty, 19 of them for crimes against the state, the government, the [[Constitution]] and military, and a further ten for criminal offenses like [[murder]] and rape. These 24 articles defined a total of 29 offenses.<ref name="AI1990">Amnesty International [http://ob.nubati.net/wiki/Illustrated_Reports_of_Amnesty_International Injustice leads to the gallows], February 1990; the relevant page as an image can be found athttp://ob.nubati.net/wiki/File:Dp199002.png</ref>
Under Article 12 of Law 765, death sentences were to be carried out by hanging after being approved by act of the [[Grand National Assembly of Turkey]] (''Türkiye Büyük Millet Meclisi''), or the TBMM. Within TBMM they were reviewed by the Judicial Committee before being voted on by parliament as a whole. This decision had to be ratified by the President, who had the power to commute death sentences on grounds of age or ill-health.<ref name="AI1990" />
By Law 4771 of 9 August 2002 (the 3rd Package for [[Accession of Turkey to the European Union|Harmonization with the European Union]]) the death penalty was abolished for peace time offences. Law 5218 of 14 July 2004 abolished the death penalty for all times.<ref>"[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3384667.stm Turkey agrees death penalty ban]," ''[[BBC News]]''. The gradual abolition of capital punishment in Turkey went as follows: 2002 for peacetime offences, 2004 for wartime offences.</ref> Turkey [[ratification|ratified]] [[European Convention on Human Rights#Protocol 13 - complete abolition of death penalty|Protocol No. 13 to the European Convention on Human Rights]], overseen by the [[Council of Europe]], in February 2006.
After the failed [[2016 Turkish coup d'état|2016 coup d'état]], some politicians are talking about restoring the death penalty.<ref>"[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/turkey-coup-erdogan-government-death-penalty-restore-attempted-istanbul-ankara-latest-dead-a7140391.html Turkey Coup: Erdogan government could restore death penalty, deputy leader warns]," ''[[The Independent]]''. Hashtag #Idamistiyorum ('I want death penalty') becomes the top trend on Turkish Twitter</ref> [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan|Erdogan]], [[President of Turkey]] since 2014, has announced (29 October 2016) that the Government (PM [[Binali Yıldırım]], [[Yıldırım Cabinet]]) will present a draft law restoring the death penalty to the [[Grand National Assembly of Turkey|Turkish Parliament]] ("and I will countersign it").<ref>spiegel.de 29 October 2016: [http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/tuerkei-erdogan-laesst-parlament-ueber-todesstrafe-abstimmen-a-1118858.html Erdogan lässt Parlament über Todesstrafe abstimmen]</ref>
On 19th March 2017, Erdogan said he would immediately approve the reinstatement of capital punishment after the upcoming constitutional referendum. <ref>http://www.presstv.com/Detail/2017/03/19/514877/turkey-erdogan-referendum-death-penalty</ref> However, this has not yet happened.
==Alternatives== The death sentence was replaced by aggravated life imprisonment (''ağırlaştırılmış müebbet hapis cezası''). According to Article 9 of Law 5275 on the Execution of Sentences<ref>An [http://www.tbmm.gov.tr/kanunlar/k5275.html online edition of Law 5275] (in Turkish on pages of the Turkish Government); accessed on 10 September 2009</ref> these prisoners are held in [[Solitary confinement|individual cells]] in [[Supermax|high security prisons]] and are allowed to exercise in a neighbouring yard one hour per day.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}}

'''Carrion insects''' are those insects associated with decomposing remains. The processes of [[decomposition]] begin within a few minutes of death.<ref name= Vass>{{cite journal|author= Vass A.A.|author2= Barshick S.A.|author3= Sega G.|author4= Caton J.|author5= Skeen J.T.|author6= Love J.C.|author7= Synstelien J.A.|title= Decomposition chemistry of human remains: A new methodology for determining the postmortem interval|journal= Journal of Forensic Sciences|volume= 47|issue= 3|pages= 542–553|year= 2002|doi=10.1520/JFS15294J|pmid=12051334}}</ref> Decomposing remains offer a temporary, changing site of concentrated resources which are exploited by a wide range of organisms, of which [[arthropod]]s are often the first to arrive and the predominant exploitive group. However, not all arthropods found on or near decomposing remains will have an active role in the decay process.<ref name= Goff>{{cite journal|last= Goff|first= M.L.|title= Estimation of postmortem interval using arthropod development and successional patterns|journal= Forensic Science Review|volume= 5|issue= 2|pages= 81–94|year= 1993}}</ref>
==Ecological roles==
Carrion insects are commonly described based on their ecological role.<ref name= Goff/><ref name= Smith>{{cite book|last= Smith|first= K.G.V.|title= A manual of forensic entomology|publisher= British Museum (Natural History & Cornell University Press)|isbn= 0-565-00990-7}}</ref> Four commonly described roles are: # [[Scavenger|Necrophagous]] species # Predators and [[Parasitism|parasites]] of necrophagous species # [[Omnivore|Omnivorous]] species # Adventive species
===Necrophagous species=== [[File:Protophormia terraenovae.jpg|thumb|Necrophagous ''Protophormia terraenovae'' (Robineau-Desvoidy).|right]] [[File:Decomposition01.jpg|thumb|<center>[[Calliphoridae]], [[Sarcophagidae]] and [[Muscidae]] on fresh porcupine corpse]] [[File:Decomposition00.jpg|thumb|<center>Larvae of blowflies and flies on 5-day old porcupine corpse]] Necrophagous species are insects/arthropods that feed directly on remains, or the fluids released from remains during the decomposition process.<ref name= Goff/><ref name= Smith/> This ecological classification includes many species of the order [[Fly|Diptera]] (true flies) from the families [[Calliphoridae]] (blowflies)and [[Flesh-fly|Sarcophagidae]] (flesh flies), and some species of the order [[Beetle|Coleoptera]] (beetles). Although specific arthropod species present at remains will vary by geographic location, some examples of common blowflies are ''[[Calliphora vicina]]'', ''[[Phormia regina]]'', ''[[Protophormia terraenovae]]'' and [[Common green bottle fly|''Lucilia sericata'']]
Necrophagous blowfly species are often the first to arrive and colonize at a site of decomposing remains.<ref name= Goff/> These species develop from eggs laid directly on the carcass and complete their life cycle on or near the remains. Because of this, necrophagous species are considered to be the most important for post-mortem interval estimations.<ref name= Watson>{{cite journal|author1=Watson E.J. |author2=Carlton C.E. |title= Spring succession of necrophilous insects on wildlife carcasses in Louisiana|journal= Journal of Medical Entomology|volume= 40|issue= 3|pages= 338–347|year= 2003|doi=10.1603/0022-2585-40.3.338}}</ref><ref name= Tabor>{{cite journal|author1=Tabor K.L. |author2=Fell R.D. |author3=Brewster C.C. |title= Insect fauna visiting carrion in Southwest Virginia|journal= Forensic Science International|volume= 150|pages= 73–80|year= 2005|doi=10.1016/j.forsciint.2004.06.041 |pmid=15837010}}</ref> The initial colonizers of greatest importance are those of the family Calliphoridae, Sarcophagidae and [[Muscidae]] (house flies), as these are typically the first insects to lay eggs at remains.<ref name= Tabor/>
The fresh stage of decomposition is characterized by the arrival of necrophagous blowflies and flesh flies. These blowflies are also strongly attracted during the bloat stage of decomposition.<ref name=Goff/> Many Dipterans, especially their larval forms, are involved in removal of material from the carcass, though not in an appreciable amount.<ref name= Putman>{{cite journal|last= Putman|first= R.J.|title= The role of carrion-frequenting arthropods in the decay process|journal= Ecological Entomology|volume= 3|pages= 133–139|year= 1978|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2311.1978.tb00911.x}}</ref> Necrophagous species of Coleoptera are most strongly attracted during the active stage of decomposition.<ref name= Goff/>
===Predators and parasites of necrophagous species=== [[File:Thanatophilus lapponicus.jpg|thumb|''Thanatophilus lapponicus'' (Herbst), Family Silphidae.|left]]
This role includes those insects which feed on, or act as parasites of, necrophagous species. These insects do not feed directly on the decomposing remains or its fluids, but are considered to be the second most forensically important ecological role.<ref name= Smith/><ref name= Payne>{{cite journal|last= Payne|first= J.A.|title= A summer carrion study of the baby pig sus scrofa Linnaeus|journal= Ecology|volume= 46|pages= 592–602|year= 1965|doi=10.2307/1934999}}</ref> Predators of necrophagous insects include species from the Coleoptera families [[Silphidae]] (carrion beetles) and [[Rove beetle|Staphylinidae]] (rove beetles).<ref name= Smith/> Parasites may include species of parasitic wasps, from the order [[Hymenoptera]] (family [[Braconidae]]).
Some species of blowflies may begin their larval development in the necrophagous role, feeding directly on remains, but become predaceous during later larval stages. These species are listed as being schizophagous, and are included in the predators and parasites ecological role.<ref name= Smith/>
The majority of beetles present at remains are there as predators of blowfly larvae, and are not directly concerned with the removal of carcass materials.<ref name= Putman/> Predaceous beetles may arrive at a site of remains as early as the bloat stage of decomposition, when there is a strong attraction of their necrophagous prey. Some of these species may also remain during active decay. During the advanced stage of decay there is an increase in those insects which are predaceous and/or parasitic on necrophagous beetles.<ref name= Goff/>
===Omnivorous species=== Omnivorous species feed on both the decomposing remains as well as other carrion associated insects, usually necrophagous species.<ref name= Goff/><ref name= Smith/> Large numbers of omnivorous insects can slow the rate at which carcass materials are removed by depleting the number of necrophagous larvae.<ref name= Early>{{cite journal|author1=Early M. |author2=Goff M.L. |title= Arthropod succession patterns in exposed carrion on the island of O'ahu, Hawaiian Islands, USA|journal= Journal of Medical Entomology|volume= 23|issue= 5|pages= 520–531|year= 1986|doi=10.1093/jmedent/23.5.520}}</ref> This category includes species of [[ant]]s, [[wasp]]s, and some species of carrion beetles.<ref name= Goff/>
===Adventive species=== Adventive species may or may not play a significant role in the decomposition of remains. Arthropods in this ecological role are not necessarily attracted to decaying remains, but use it as an extension of their natural habitats. Adventive species originate within the vegetation and soils surrounding decomposing remains. These insects may visit remains from time to time, or use them for concealment,<ref name= Campobasso>{{cite journal|author1=Campobasso C.P. |author2=Di Vella G. |author3=Introna F. |title= Factors affecting decomposition and Diptera colonization|journal= Forensic Science International|volume= 120|pages= 18–27|year= 2001|doi=10.1016/S0379-0738(01)00411-X|pmid=11457604}}</ref> but their presence can only be accounted for by chance.<ref name= Goff/> They may also become predators of necrophagous species found at remains.<ref name= Campobasso/> Adventive species include [[springtail]]s, [[centipede]]s and [[spider]]s.<ref name= Smith/>
The diagram below shows the relationship between each ecological role and a site of decaying remains. [[File:Carrion insect trophic relationships.png|thumb|Trophic level relationships between ecological roles of carrion insects. Image adapted from Smith (1986).|centre]]
==Condensed ecological roles==
The ecological roles described above can further be condensed into two broad, general classifications:<ref name= Marchenko>{{cite journal|last= Marchenko|first= M.I.|title= Medicolegal relevance of cadaver entomofauna for the determination of the time of death|journal= Forensic Science International|volume= 120|pages= 89–109|year= 2001|doi=10.1016/s0379-0738(01)00416-9}}</ref> # Properly cadaveric entomofauna # Arbitrary entomofauna of a cadaver
===Properly cadaveric entomofauna=== This classification consists of necrobiont insects which use decaying remains as a permanent environment necessary for their life and development. Necrobiont insects includes necrophagous and entomophagous trophic specializations,<ref name= Marchenko/> or necrophagous, predaceous/parasitic and omnivorous species.
===Arbitrary entomofauna of a cadaver=== Some insects or arthropods visit sites of carrion, but do not colonize them.<ref name= Tabor/> This classification consists of those insects for which decomposing remains are not a permanent feature for development.<ref name= Marchenko/> The adventive trophic specialization falls into this category.
==Forensic relevance== {{See also|Forensic entomological decomposition}}
Each group or species of insect will be attracted to decomposing remains at different stages of decomposition, as changes within the remains result in the availability of different resources. The predictable order in which the above described insect groups are attracted to and observed on remains is referred to as a succession pattern, and can be used in forensic investigations to estimate the [[post-mortem interval]] (PMI) or time since death.<ref name= Anderson>{{cite journal|author1=Anderson G.S. |author2=VanLaerhoven S.L. |title= Initial studies on insect succession on carrion in southwestern British Columbia|journal= Journal of Forensic Sciences|volume= 41|issue= 4|pages= 617–625|year= 1996|doi=10.1520/JFS13964J}}</ref> This method of PMI estimation is most useful in the later stages of decomposition.<ref name= Tabor1>{{cite journal|author= Tabor, K.L.|author2= Brewster, C.C.|author3= Fell, R.D.|last-author-amp= yes|title= Analysis of the successional patterns of insects on carrion in Southwest Virginia|journal= Journal of Medical Entomology|volume= 41|issue= 4|pages= 785–795|year= 2004|doi=10.1603/0022-2585-41.4.785}}</ref>
A second method of PMI determination, in early stages of decomposition, by insect evidence utilizes the development rate of colonizing arthropods. This method is usually applied to necrophagous blowflies, as they are often the first to colonize and are associated with remains for the longest period. Development rates are only useful in forensic investigations until the first new generation has completed development and left the remains.<ref name= Goff/>

'''Computational genomics''' (often referred to as Computational Genetics) refers to the use of computational and statistical analysis to decipher biology from [[genome sequence]]s and related data,<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Koonin EV | title = Computational genomics | journal = Current Biology | volume = 11 | issue = 5 | pages = R155–8 | date = March 2001 | pmid = 11267880 | doi = 10.1016/S0960-9822(01)00081-1 | url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0960-9822(01)00081-1 }}</ref> including both [[DNA]] and [[RNA]] sequence as well as other "post-genomic" data (i.e., experimental data obtained with technologies that require the genome sequence, such as genomic [[DNA microarrays]]). These, in combination with computational and statistical approaches to understanding the function of the genes and statistical association analysis, this field is also often referred to as [[Computational and Statistical Genetics]]/genomics. As such, computational genomics may be regarded as a subset of [[bioinformatics]] and [[computational biology]], but with a focus on using whole genomes (rather than individual genes) to understand the principles of how the DNA of a species controls its biology at the molecular level and beyond. With the current abundance of massive biological datasets, computational studies have become one of the most important means to biological discovery.<ref name="MIT">[http://www.eecs.mit.edu/bioeecs/CompGenProt.html Computational Genomics and Proteomics at MIT]</ref>
==History== The roots of computational genomics are shared with those of [[bioinformatics]]. During the 1960s, [[Margaret Dayhoff]] and others at the National Biomedical Research Foundation assembled databases of homologous protein sequences for evolutionary study.<ref>{{cite book |last=Mount |first=David | name-list-format = vanc |title=Bioinformatics, Sequence and Genome Analysis |publisher=Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press |year=2000 |isbn=978-0-87969-597-2 |pages=2–3 }}</ref> Their research developed a [[phylogenetic tree]] that determined the evolutionary changes that were required for a particular protein to change into another protein based on the underlying [[amino acid]] sequences. This led them to create a scoring matrix that assessed the likelihood of one protein being related to another.
Beginning in the 1980s, databases of genome sequences began to be recorded, but this presented new challenges in the form of searching and comparing the databases of gene information. Unlike text-searching algorithms that are used on websites such as Google or Wikipedia, searching for sections of genetic similarity requires one to find strings that are not simply identical, but similar. This led to the development of the [[Needleman-Wunsch algorithm]], which is a [[dynamic programming]] algorithm for comparing sets of amino acid sequences with each other by using scoring matrices derived from the earlier research by Dayhoff. Later, the [[BLAST]] algorithm was developed for performing fast, optimized searches of gene sequence databases. BLAST and its derivatives are probably the most widely used algorithms for this purpose.<ref>{{cite book |vauthors = Brown TA |title=Genomes |publisher=Wiley |year=1999 |isbn=978-0-471-31618-3 }}</ref>
The emergence of the phrase "computational genomics" coincides with the availability of complete sequenced genomes in the mid-to-late 1990s. The first meeting of the Annual Conference on Computational Genomics was organized by scientists from [[The Institute for Genomic Research]] (TIGR) in 1998, providing a forum for this speciality and effectively distinguishing this area of science from the more general fields of [[Genomics]] or [[Computational Biology]].{{cn|date=October 2018}} The first use of this term in scientific literature, according to [[MEDLINE]] abstracts, was just one year earlier in [[Nucleic Acids Research]].<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Wagner A | title = A computational genomics approach to the identification of gene networks | journal = Nucleic Acids Research | volume = 25 | issue = 18 | pages = 3594–604 | date = September 1997 | pmid = 9278479 | pmc = 146952 | doi = 10.1093/nar/25.18.3594 | url = http://nar.oxfordjournals.org/content/25/18/3594.long }}</ref> The final Computational Genomics conference was held in 2006, featuring a keynote talk by Nobel Laureate [[Barry Marshall]], co-discoverer of the link between [[Helicobacter pylori]] and stomach ulcers. As of 2014, the leading conferences in the field include [[Intelligent Systems for Molecular Biology]] (ISMB) and [[Research in Computational Molecular Biology]] (RECOMB).
The development of computer-assisted mathematics (using products such as [[Mathematica]] or [[Matlab]]) has helped engineers, mathematicians and computer scientists to start operating in this domain, and a public collection of case studies and demonstrations is growing, ranging from whole genome comparisons to [[gene expression]] analysis.<ref>{{cite book | vauthors = Cristianini N, Hahn M |title=Introduction to Computational Genomics |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2006 |isbn=978-0-521-67191-0 |url=http://www.computational-genomics.net/}}</ref> This has increased the introduction of different ideas, including concepts from systems and control, information theory, strings analysis and data mining. It is anticipated that computational approaches will become and remain a standard topic for research and teaching, while students fluent in both topics start being formed in the multiple courses created in the past few years.
==Contributions of computational genomics research to biology== Contributions of computational genomics research to biology include:<ref name="MIT"/> * proposing [[cellular signalling]] networks * proposing mechanisms of genome evolution * predict precise locations of all human [[genes]] using [[comparative genomics]] techniques with several mammalian and vertebrate [[species]] * predict [[Conservation (genetics)|conserved]] genomic regions that are related to early [[embryonic development]] * discover potential links between repeated sequence motifs and tissue-specific [[gene expression]] * measure regions of genomes that have undergone unusually rapid evolution
